channel.title: ASF JIRA
channel.description: This file is an XML representation of an issue

item.title: [OAK-643] Very high memory usage with 6000 child nodes
item.description:
The following test case gets slower and slower the more child nodes are added to a node, until (I think) it eventually runs out of memory. I have analyzed a heap dump, and the problem seems to be the cache in oak-core:

@Test
public void testManyChildren() throws RepositoryException {
    Session session = getAdminSession();
    Node root = session.getRootNode().addNode("testRoot");
    session.save();
    int count = 100;
    for (int j = 0; j < 10; j++) {
        Node test = root.
                addNode("test" + j, "nt:folder");
        session.save();
        long time = System.currentTimeMillis();
        for (int i = 0; i < count; i++) {
            test.addNode("child" + i, "nt:folder");
            if ((i % 100) == 0) {
                session.save();
            }
        }
        System.out.println(
                count + " nodes in " + 
                (System.currentTimeMillis() - time) + " ms");
        count *= 2;
    }
}

Output when using the MicroKernelImpl (persisted to disk):

100 nodes in 757 ms
200 nodes in 538 ms
400 nodes in 957 ms
800 nodes in 1630 ms
1600 nodes in 3245 ms
3200 nodes in 5389 ms
6400 nodes in 47581 ms
12800 nodes in 377216 ms
java.lang.OutOfMemoryError: Java heap space

Problem Suspect 1:
74 MB (57.72%) in com.google.common.cache.LocalCache$Segment[]
in a thread, see below

Problem Suspect 2:
39 MB (30.76%) in org.apache.jackrabbit.mk.store.DefaultRevisionStore
(this might be the regular node cache)

Problem Suspect 3:
13 MB (10.59%) in org.h2.store.PageStore
(16 MB is the default cache size for the H2 database,
so this isn't a leak)

The thread for suspect 1 is:

at java.util.LinkedHashMap.createEntry(ILjava/lang/Object;Ljava/lang/Object;I)V (LinkedHashMap.java:424)
  at java.util.LinkedHashMap.addEntry(ILjava/lang/Object;Ljava/lang/Object;I)V (LinkedHashMap.java:406)
  at java.util.HashMap.put(Ljava/lang/Object;Ljava/lang/Object;)Ljava/lang/Object; (HashMap.java:385)
  at org.apache.jackrabbit.oak.kernel.KernelNodeState.init()V (KernelNodeState.java:142)
  at org.apache.jackrabbit.oak.kernel.KernelNodeState.equals(Ljava/lang/Object;)Z (KernelNodeState.java:310)
  at org.apache.jackrabbit.oak.spi.state.AbstractNodeState.compareAgainstBaseState(Lorg/apache/jackrabbit/oak/spi/state/NodeState;Lorg/apache/jackrabbit/oak/spi/state/NodeStateDiff;)V (AbstractNodeState.java:149)
  at org.apache.jackrabbit.oak.kernel.KernelNodeState.compareAgainstBaseState(Lorg/apache/jackrabbit/oak/spi/state/NodeState;Lorg/apache/jackrabbit/oak/spi/state/NodeStateDiff;)V (KernelNodeState.java:286)
  at org.apache.jackrabbit.oak.plugins.commit.MergingNodeStateDiff.merge(Lorg/apache/jackrabbit/oak/spi/state/NodeState;Lorg/apache/jackrabbit/oak/spi/state/NodeState;Lorg/apache/jackrabbit/oak/spi/state/NodeBuilder;Lorg/apache/jackrabbit/oak/spi/commit/ConflictHandler;)Lorg/apache/jackrabbit/oak/spi/state/NodeState; (MergingNodeStateDiff.java:69)
  at org.apache.jackrabbit.oak.plugins.commit.MergingNodeStateDiff.childNodeChanged(Ljava/lang/String;Lorg/apache/jackrabbit/oak/spi/state/NodeState;Lorg/apache/jackrabbit/oak/spi/state/NodeState;)V (MergingNodeStateDiff.java:90)
  at org.apache.jackrabbit.oak.spi.state.AbstractNodeState.compareAgainstBaseState(Lorg/apache/jackrabbit/oak/spi/state/NodeState;Lorg/apache/jackrabbit/oak/spi/state/NodeStateDiff;)V (AbstractNodeState.java:150)
  at org.apache.jackrabbit.oak.kernel.KernelNodeState.compareAgainstBaseState(Lorg/apache/jackrabbit/oak/spi/state/NodeState;Lorg/apache/jackrabbit/oak/spi/state/NodeStateDiff;)V (KernelNodeState.java:286)
  at org.apache.jackrabbit.oak.plugins.commit.MergingNodeStateDiff.merge(Lorg/apache/jackrabbit/oak/spi/state/NodeState;Lorg/apache/jackrabbit/oak/spi/state/NodeState;Lorg/apache/jackrabbit/oak/spi/state/NodeBuilder;Lorg/apache/jackrabbit/oak/spi/commit/ConflictHandler;)Lorg/apache/jackrabbit/oak/spi/state/NodeState; (MergingNodeStateDiff.java:69)
  at org.apache.jackrabbit.oak.plugins.commit.MergingNodeStateDiff.merge(Lorg/apache/jackrabbit/oak/spi/state/NodeState;Lorg/apache/jackrabbit/oak/spi/state/NodeState;Lorg/apache/jackrabbit/oak/spi/commit/ConflictHandler;)Lorg/apache/jackrabbit/oak/spi/state/NodeState; (MergingNodeStateDiff.java:64)
  at org.apache.jackrabbit.oak.plugins.commit.ConflictHook.processCommit(Lorg/apache/jackrabbit/oak/spi/state/NodeState;Lorg/apache/jackrabbit/oak/spi/state/NodeState;)Lorg/apache/jackrabbit/oak/spi/state/NodeState; (ConflictHook.java:34)
  at org.apache.jackrabbit.oak.spi.commit.CompositeHook.processCommit(Lorg/apache/jackrabbit/oak/spi/state/NodeState;Lorg/apache/jackrabbit/oak/spi/state/NodeState;)Lorg/apache/jackrabbit/oak/spi/state/NodeState; (CompositeHook.java:59)
  at org.apache.jackrabbit.oak.spi.commit.CompositeHook.processCommit(Lorg/apache/jackrabbit/oak/spi/state/NodeState;Lorg/apache/jackrabbit/oak/spi/state/NodeState;)Lorg/apache/jackrabbit/oak/spi/state/NodeState; (CompositeHook.java:59)
  at org.apache.jackrabbit.oak.kernel.KernelNodeStoreBranch.merge(Lorg/apache/jackrabbit/oak/spi/commit/CommitHook;)Lorg/apache/jackrabbit/oak/spi/state/NodeState; (KernelNodeStoreBranch.java:128)
  at org.apache.jackrabbit.oak.core.RootImpl$2.run()Lorg/apache/jackrabbit/oak/api/CommitFailedException; (RootImpl.java:257)
  at org.apache.jackrabbit.oak.core.RootImpl$2.run()Ljava/lang/Object; (RootImpl.java:253)
  at java.security.AccessController.doPrivileged(Ljava/security/PrivilegedAction;Ljava/security/AccessControlContext;)Ljava/lang/Object; (Native Method)
  at javax.security.auth.Subject.doAs(Ljavax/security/auth/Subject;Ljava/security/PrivilegedAction;)Ljava/lang/Object; (Subject.java:337)
  at org.apache.jackrabbit.oak.core.RootImpl.commit()V (RootImpl.java:252)
  at org.apache.jackrabbit.oak.jcr.SessionDelegate.save()V (SessionDelegate.java:255)
item.summary: Very high memory usage with 6000 child nodes

status.description: The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.

comments.comment: The key here is AbstractNodeState.compareAgainstBaseState; the node state comparison falls back on the AbstractNodeState that uses a very generic (thus inefficient) comparison algorithm. The solution would be to use MicroKernel.diff in KernelNodeState.compareAgainstBaseState instead of falling back to the AbstractNodeState implementation.
This is probably also related to OAK-373. The cache in KernelNodeStore only has a limit for the number of entries (10k) but doesn't take the size of an entry into account.

Thanks Marcel, I linked OAK-373.

I guess we need to change the cache to account for the memory usage of each entry. To do that, each cache entry (KernelNodeState objects) would need to be internally immutable, or the cache would need to be informed when the size of an entry changes. I would prefer immutable objects, but I'm not sure if that's feasible.

Jukka, as far as I remember you once said that entries in this cache are not internally immutable at the moment? I don't currently see that in the code, did this change recently?

> The key here is AbstractNodeState.compareAgainstBaseState

I don't currently see how this is related to this (memory usage) problem. I think you talk about a different problem, about a performance problem, right?

KernelNodeStates are lazy initialized when they are already in the cache. See KernelNodeState.init(). The Guava cache is designed to weigh the cached item when it is added to the cache.

The key here is AbstractNodeState.compareAgainstBaseState

Jukka is probably refering to the fact that adding a child node to a parent with many children forces loading all of the children later to find out, which one was added. Delegating this to the MicroKernel.diff() might be more efficent in this case.

Jukka is probably refering to the fact that ...

Indeed. The code iterates through all the child nodes, which at these sizes end up quickly filling up the 10k slots of the cache in KernelNodeStore. Many of those entries are fairly large, since each save() call in the code results in a new revision and thus also a new version of the flat parent node, each of which contains a map of up to 10k child name->path mappings. With an average size of 7-8kB per cached KernelNodeState instance, we get to the mentioned 74MB.

As mentioned earlier, I think the KernelNodeState caching, at least as currently implemented is in many ways troublesome. My suggestion is to do something like what I'm now drafting in the SegmentMK (where optimizing memory use is one of the key ideas), but I'd love to see also alternative ideas (or better yet, code).

I also think the approach the SegmentMK takes is better. For the current MicroKernelImpl this would mean there should also be a NodeStore implementation which directly hooks into the MicroKernelImpl internals. Then the only and primary cache would be the cache in DefaultRevisionStore. But is it really worth the effort?

Further optimized caching in KernelNodeStore a bit in revision: 1450145

The test now just runs for a very long time (with -Xmx128m) and didn't run out of memory so far on my machine. Though, it is still working on 51200 child nodes after it reported '25600 nodes in 1440293 ms'.

Attached patch addresses two issues:

1) memory usage is reduced by limiting the number of child nodes kept in memory to 1000. This is the value we initially had. At some point we increased it to 10k to address a performance issue with the initial MongoMK implementation. I think it's better to go with a lower value. First it hides potential issues when there are many child nodes, which you only see when you have more than 10k child nodes. Second, it uses quite some memory. The patch is rather work in progress, because the cache in KernelNodeStore still keeps multiple revisions of a node with many child nodes. This may still lead to increased memory usage. However, the test provided by Thomas passes with this patch.

2) The time to add child nodes increased significantly the more child nodes already existed. With this patch KernelNodeState uses MK.diff() once more than 1000 child nodes exist. The time to add more child nodes now stays rather stable. E.g. the wikipedia benchmark output says:

Apache Jackrabbit Oak 0.7-SNAPSHOT
Oak-Default: Wikipedia import benchmark
Importing fowiki-latest-pages-articles.xml...
Added 1000 pages in 3 seconds (3.22ms/page)
Added 2000 pages in 6 seconds (3.30ms/page)
Added 3000 pages in 8 seconds (2.99ms/page)
Added 4000 pages in 11 seconds (2.80ms/page)
Added 5000 pages in 14 seconds (2.92ms/page)
Added 6000 pages in 16 seconds (2.68ms/page)
Added 7000 pages in 19 seconds (2.78ms/page)
Added 8000 pages in 21 seconds (2.65ms/page)
Added 9000 pages in 24 seconds (2.74ms/page)
Added 10000 pages in 26 seconds (2.62ms/page)
Added 11000 pages in 27 seconds (2.53ms/page)
Added 12000 pages in 31 seconds (2.62ms/page)
Imported 12148 pages in 51 seconds (4.20ms/page)

Some interesting observation about the MicroKernelImpl (the one based on H2). The final merge produces a huge commit, which is more than 60 MB in size. Subsequent reading from the MicroKernel is quite slow, because resolving the root node revision via the commit does not fit into 32 MB cache in DefaultRevisionStore. The commit is therefore read from H2 on every MK read access.

Applied patch and test case in revision: 1451247

I'll still leave this issue open and have a look at how to better control the size of the cache in KernelNodeStore.
Recent patch turns the cache in KernelNodeStore into one with a memory limit.
